citation.article-title: Branchiibius hedensis gen. nov., sp. nov., an actinobacterium isolated from a Japanese codling (Physiculus japonicus)
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Branchiibius [Bran.chi.i.bi′us. L. pl. n. branchiae the gills of fish; N.L. masc. n. bius (from Gr. masc. n. bios) life; N.L. masc. n. Branchiibius a life existing in gills of fish].
Cells are Gram-stain-positive, coccoid (0.7×0.9 µm), halotolerant, non-motile and aerobic to microaerobic.
Colonies are circular, convex, entire, smooth and pale yellow.
The cell-wall peptidoglycan contains l-Lys, d-Ser, l-Ser, Gly, d-Glu and d-Ala.
The acyl type of the muramic acid in the peptidoglycan is acetyl.

Phospholipids are phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol and one unidentified phospholipid, and whole-cell sugars are galactose, mannose, rhamnose, ribose, glucose and arabinose.
The major fatty acids are C17 : 1 cis-9, C18 : 1 cis-9 and iso-C16 : 0.
Phylogenetically, the genus is a member of the family Dermacoccaceae and the type species is Branchibius hedensis.
